body:
Guess this sounds reasonable. As a temporary workaround, you could just run `make sfml-network`, but you'd have to install the files manually.

Only downside/quirk I could think right now, would be the fact that you'd still install the full headers, even those for the modules not being built.

> As a temporary workaround, you could just run make sfml-network, but you'd have to install the files manually.

Nop, the problem is at configure time. As you noticed, selective compilation is already possible with targets. But right now you still have to _configure_ all the modules (and therefore find all the dependant libraries) even if you're only going to build sfml-network.

So this feature would consist in adding CMake options such as SFML_BUILD_SYSTEM, SFML_BUILD_AUDIO, etc. to make CMake completely ignore the unselected modules.

Ah, right. The external/system dependencies not being bundled... completely forgot about those. Think this is actually rather easy to add, going to try it a bit later today if I find the time to do it.

Okay, so we've got a small hen and egg problem here:

Theoretically, a module like _sfml-window_ has to ensure its dependencies (here: _sfml-system_) are considered for building. As such you'd define the projects from top to bottom. However, for CMake to find/link dependencies properly, they have to be defined from bottom to top.

Not sure how to solve this without redundant dependency definitions in two locations.

Just a quick morning thought: For sfml-system, let's assume the user always wants it (wouldn't make much sense otherwise and it simplify things a bit), then on the user side we could have SFML_BUILD_WINDOW/GRAPHICS/AUDIO/NETWORK where SFML_BUILD_WINDOW would be automatically set to true if SFML_BUILD_GRAPHICS is true.

Then on the implementation side, do we need something special besides if statements?

Well, yes, I could just introduce all variables in one locations and check the dependencies there as well.

I would have preferred putting everything into the macro used to create the targets on the fly, but guess that's not going to happen that easily.

You can't do this into the macros, when they are called it's already too late (all the dependencies search is done before). These variables must be defined in a top-level CMakelists.txt (such as src/SFML) and the whole module directory must be skipped if the corresponding option is unchecked.

@LaurentGomila Exactly my hen and egg problem. :)

But yeah, going with the top level approach.

issue.title: Added CMake variables to select the modules to be built
issue.body:
This addresses issue #798.

The only leftover issue I see is the fact that on most platforms we're always installing most third party dependencies, even if the modules aren't built.

body: There you go. give it a try please. :)
